comments.text:
+David Rosa A permanent magnet puts out a magnetic field because each of 
its atoms has its own magnetic field (created by electron imbalance in the 
atom) and these fields are all aligned. However, just having a field does 
not make a magnet a source of *perpetual* energy; it makes it more a source 
of *potential* energy, particularly when you have an ion or some other 
charged particle inserted into the magnet's field. The fields of the 
charged particle (and the particle being charged is very important) and the 
magnet may interact to produce forces and subsequently energy, but the 
fields on their own really just sort of sit there if they have nothing to 
act on.

I think a good analogy would be a gravitational field. On its own, a 
gravitational field doesn't really do anything. It sits there, but it 
doesn't have an object to act upon. But if you put an object some distance 
from the center of this field, the object will be affected (in this case 
attracted!) and fall towards the center, producing kinetic energy. The 
magnetic field, like a gravitational field, may affect an object placed 
some distance from the center of its field. These fields are *potential* 
fields. Potential fields basically just create the opportunity for anything 
in them to change energy state. In the case of gravity, the field creates 
potential for anything that has mass. A magnetic field , however, creates a 
potential for particles or objects that have charge. With either of them, 
the object placed in the field has the potential to change, and this is its *potential 
energy*.

Anyway, sorry for the really long explanation, but I hope this clears up 
any problems you were having. Have a nice day/evening/whatever! :)

comments.text:
They are intimately related, but not exactly the same. Electric fields are 
created by differences in voltage: the higher the voltage, the stronger 
will be the resultant field. Magnetic fields are created when electric 
current flows: the greater the current, the stronger the magnetic field. An 
electric field will exist even when there is no current flowing. If current 
does flow, the strength of the magnetic field will vary with power 
consumption but the electric field strength will be constant.

*MinutePhysics & Veritasium - MAGNETS: How Do They Work?*
*By Henry Reich (MinutePhysics) & Derek Muller (Veritasium).*
September 23, 2013 youtu.be/hFAOXdXZ5TM (6 min 26 sec)

Derek Muller (1:52): *"(W)hy do objects with mass and energy attract each 
other gravitationally? No one knows. We just know that's the way the 
universe works."*

*Comment:* I'm staggered that knowledgeable people remain still stuck to 
the Newtonian pre-relativistic description of gravitation. Objects with 
mass and energy don't attract each other gravitationally, their accelerated 
and/or non-linear motion isn't but the direct consequence of the curvature 
of space-time continuum.

*<< In a field model, rather than two particles attracting each other, the 
particles distort spacetime via their mass, and this distortion is what is 
perceived and measured as a "force". In such a model one states that matter 
moves in certain ways in response to the curvature of spacetime,[1] and 
that there is either no gravitational force,[2] or that gravity is a 
fictitious force.[3] >>*

phenomenon itself is a consequence of the curvature of spacetime governing

*<< Spacetime around a massive object (such as a galaxy cluster or a black 
hole) is curved, and as a result light rays from a background source (such 
as a galaxy) propagating through spacetime are bent. The lensing effect can 
magnify and distort the image of the background source.*

*Unlike an optical lens, maximum 'bending' occurs closest to, and minimum 
'bending' furthest from, the center of a gravitational lens. Consequently, 
a gravitational lens has no single focal point, but a focal line instead. 
If the (light) source, the massive lensing object, and the observer lie in 
a straight line, the original light source will appear as a ring around the 
massive lensing object. If there is any misalignment the observer will see 
an arc segment instead. >>*
 . . . 
*<< Gravitational lenses act equally on all kinds of electromagnetic 
radiation, not just visible light. Weak lensing effects are being studied 
for the cosmic microwave background as well as galaxy surveys. Strong 
lenses have been observed in radio and x-ray regimes as well. If a strong 
lens produces multiple images, there will be a relative time delay between 
two paths: that is, in one image the lensed object will be observed before 
the other image. >>*
en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gravitational_lens#Description 

*<< The first frame-dragging effect was derived in 1918, in the framework 
of general relativity, by the Austrian physicists Josef Lense and Hans 
Thirring, and is also known as the Lense–Thirring effect.[1][2][3] They 
predicted that the rotation of a massive object would distort the spacetime 
metric, making the orbit of a nearby test particle precess. This does not 
happen in Newtonian mechanics for which the gravitational field of a body 
depends only on its mass, not on its rotation. >>*
en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frame-dragging

moves in certain ways in response to the curvature of spacetime,[1] and 
that there is either no gravitational force,[2] or that gravity is a 
fictitious force.[3] >>*
en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gravitational_field 

*References:*

*<< We have already seen above that Einstein's equation can be interpreted 
as requiring that "matter cause curvature in space-time," and that it can 
also be interpreted as requiring that "matter move in certain ways in 
response to curvature in space-time." Gravitation thus arises as follows. 
Let there be, say, two massive bodies in the world. Then, according to 
Einstein's equation, each will cause a certain amount of curvature in 
space-time. Further, according to Einstein's equation, each body will be 
forced to move in a certain way in response to the curvature caused by the 
other. The net result, then, is that each body influences the other. It is 
just this influence that we call gravitation. The idea is that the 
curvature of the space-time geometry acts as a sort of intermediary between 
two bodies. It is essentially the gravitational field. >>*

1. Geroch, Robert (1981). *General relativity from A to B.* *University of 
Chicago Press. p. 181. ISBN 0-226-28864-1., Chapter 7, page 181*
books.google.com/books?id=UkxPpqHs0RkC&pg=PA181 


*<< Gravity is treated very differently in Newton's and Einstein's 
theories. **According to the general theory of relativity there is no 
gravitational force.** The principle of equivalence says that the physical 
effects of permanent gravitational fields and those due to the acceleration 
or rotation of the reference frame are equivalent. >>*

2. Grøn, Øyvind; Hervik, Sigbjørn (2007). *Einstein's general theory of 
relativity; with modern applications in cosmology.* *Springer Japan. p. 
256. ISBN 0-387-69199-5., Chapter 10, page 256*
books.google.com/books?id=COqUEa5M6O0C&pg=PA256

curved space-time, just as the ants follow geodesics on the apple's skin. 
>>*

*<< Given that **Einstein's general theory does not involve the idea of 
gravity as a force,** how does the gravitational "force" that is a feature 
of the Newtonian theory arise? We remarked in the Introduction that in a 
local inertial frame (a freely falling nonrotating reference system 
occupying a small region of space-time) the laws of physics are those of 
special relativity, an in particular free particles (those moving under 
gravity alone) follow straight-line paths with constant speed, so for these 
frames there is no acceleration and consequently no "force." When 
discussing gravity in Newtonian terms, it is customary to insist that the 
frame used is nonrotating (so there are no centrifugal or Coriolis 
"forces"), but one does not normally use a frame that is freely falling, 
and it is this use of nonfreely falling frames that gives rise to 
gravitational forces. Just as the fictitious forces associated with 
rotation (the centrifugal and the Coriolis forces) can be transformed away 
(locally) by changing to a nonrotating frame, so can **the fictitious force 
of gravity** be transformed away by changing to a freely falling frame. >>*

3. J. Foster, J. D. Nightingale, J. Foster, J. D. Nightingale; J. Foster, 
J. D. Nightingale, J. Foster, J. D. Nightingale (2006). *A short course in

Light is an electromagnetic wave, so it has a magnetic field component to 
it.
But apart from that you are comparing apples and oranges, you are affected 
by photons, because they carry energy and interact with electrons in your 
body. This can change chemical substances in your body since electrons are 
what connect atoms to form molecules, this is if the photon has enough 
energy. Microwaves can interact using a whole different "mechanic" that has 
to do with the arrangement of water molecules.

A magnet on the other hand has to do with charges/moving charges. Your body 
doesn't really have many of moving charges and generally it's charges are 
in equilibrium.

get a strong enough magnetic field and it starts to have an effect, search 
"frog in a magnetic field" and you can read articles/see videos on how 
putting a frog in a very strong magnetic field can make it levitate.

comments.text:
+Laszlo Szabo, a couple of problems here:

1. Consider a case where both cannot happen, such as a planet staying still 
and moving at the same time in the same way. By saying both can happen, 
such a person is now shutting off their logic and is now willing to accept 
anything ever. If we accept that something can be moving and not moving at 
the same time, than what is stopping us from illogical claims, such as one 
claiming they drew a 4-sided triangle? This is not logical and we reject 
such a claim.

Even if this results in the multiverse mentioned above, there's still 
problems here:

2. Saying a multiverse is the solution is running away as this is never 
provable. It's not the only solution to the problem in the video... so why 
do we jump to that conclusion and not any other answer, such as saying 
there was a reason for its existence? We should use common sense and say 
that contradictions do not exist in the Universe, and such a case cannot 
exist. Something cannot be dead and alive at the same time. Saying a 
multiverse is something not provable, so the one making the claim is not 
certain of his answer and should be questioned as to why they chose that 
answer over any other answer.

3. Even if the solution is a multiverse, this still gives us more questions 
than answers. Like, if a cat was alive and dead at the same time, and you 
saw the dead cat in this Universe we are in right now, then this brings the 
question again... why do you see a dead cat in this Universe and not the 
live one? In the current Universe, if you opened the box, you only see 1 
outcome. Not both. Both outcomes cannot happen in 1 Universe. You will only 
see one outcome.

comments.text:
+Yousef Shanawany The reason he doesn't understand you is because most 
people -- including physicists -- are completely philosophically inept. 
Many of them don't possess even the most basic of logical reasoning.

What most of them do not understand is that probabilities are merely 
mathematical concepts. Probabilities do not actually exist other than in 
our minds. The reason we calculate probabilities to begin with is for the 
very reason that we do not know something for certain. If we did, we would 
not need to calculate those probabilities!

Nonetheless, I agree that the TRUE probability was NOT exactly 50-50. The 
50% is merely an incomplete approximation due to incomplete or lacking 
information. As a matter of fact, if you think about it, probabilities in 
the Universe could be said to be either 100% or 0% and never in between 
because something either happens or it doesn't. To say otherwise would be a 
logical contradiction. So in other words, the only reason we get numbers in 
between 0 and 100 is because of HUMAN limitations. If we could for example, 
have ALL of the pertinent information of a system, we could in this 
hypothetical case give an EXACT determination of what was to happen. This 
would come out to exactly 0 or 100.

Also, most physicists will give you the same ramblings such as what you 
have encountered here. They will tell you that your question is merely a 
philosophical one (as if to somehow imply that philosophy is "lesser" of a 
subject). Regardless, most philosophers don't study physics, so they have 
no idea either. That now realistically leaves us with literally NO ONE to 
explain natural phenomena. I personally do not buy into this. They are 
merely "passing the buck" so to speak to evade the difficult questions.

of an explanation. What kind of explanation would satisfy you? If you can't

comments.text:
+Corey Carnes "So which is a more accurate description of an atom. "Frozen" 
energy or super energy saturated spacetime?"

Well. sort of both and sort of neither... (possibly). Let me take a few 
paragraphs to explain.

Mass is now defined as the "rest" energy of a particle (a particle in the 
same inertial reference frame as us). So in a sense from someone on the 
outside of a particle the energy can be somewhat thought of as "frozen." 
However, all particles have a ground state and all are therefore moving. 
ALL particles are like kids with ADHD (can never sit still...) so being 
"frozen" doesn't make sense. Even if they're not moving from point A to B 
they are still oscillating/randomly moving within a small distance. 
Particles tend to return to their ground state because excited states are 
unstable but it is never a "frozen state" as dictated by the uncertainty 
principle. Solids which appear to be frozen to macroscopic objects like us 
are actually teaming with a large number of particles all moving to and 
fro. Many particles actually receive much of their mass from the energy 
contained within the kinetic energy of its constituent parts. A lot of mass 
is actually caused by "unfrozen" energy (kinetic energy) if you look close 
enough.

However, there is something called the Higgs field that theoretically 
exists that's supposed to couple with matter to give it mass. There's an 
experiment where they have used a Bose-Einstein condensate to slow light 
down to almost zero speed within the condensate. The particles in the 
condensate couple with (interact with) the photon slowing it down almost 
like it's stuck in mud (but the real way it's doing it is much 
different...). To fully explain the idea I would have to explain the idea 
behind wavepackets, quantum tunneling, and refraction but that would take 
awhile (It's a quantum effect). LASERs, phased array radars (found on US 
destroyers/cruisers), and LRADs (long range acoustic devices for crowd 
control) use the wavepacket idea to turn a bunch of waves into beam that 
propagates like a particle/beam. In all three cases a bunch of waves almost 
nearly line up with very close frequencies/wavelengths to form a wave 
packet that disperses slower (AKA more particle like). The math is pretty 
cool and identical to that found in Quantum Mechanics. Whenever a whole 
bunch of waves that are almost identical almost perfectly line up they 
create a central blob that's particle like. On naval vessels 3,000 little 
radar antennas shoot off in each array (the arrays look like gray stop 
signs on the ships) at slightly different times (if they were identical it 
would be perfectly coherent) in a way to make one beam that points in one 
direction out of the 3,000 waves (so you don't have to mechanically point 
the radar). A LASER creates gazillions of photons that are almost perfectly 
coherent (because Bosons tend to do that under stimulated emission) 
creating a beam like effect. The condensate is a whole bunch of particles 
in basically the exact same quantum state so their interactions with the 
photon creates a reverse EMF effect making an effect where the photon looks 
like its moving really slow (the photon is still moving at C but the 
coupling is causing a localized wavepacket carrying the net energy of the 
photon. The slow moving photon then has a "rest" energy AKA a "mass." The 
Schrodinger wave equation itself creates an infinite number of wavelets 
(spread out over say space and/or momentum for example) that creates a 
wavepacket for all solutions. Therefore this idea is pretty important.

The Higgs field is supposed to do something similar. This would mean that 
matter is energy bogged down by the Higgs field. By the way scientists 
think they have found the Higgs Boson that creates the Higgs field. The 
Higgs Field would interact with matter to create a wavepacket like effect 
causing matter to be localized in one small area and giving it a "mass." 

"or super energy saturated spacetime"

To tackle this one I will start with Quantum Field Theory. Quantum Field 
Theory sums up an infinite amount of wavelets with slightly different 
frequencies. The problem with the theory is that the equations blow up to 
infinite energy because the really really short wavelengths don't converge 
(that is the energy approaches infinity). To combat this QFT did something 
called "renormalization." This basically means that the theory only works 
if at some really tiny distance (smallest wavelength) the equation crops 
off. This is one of the reasons for the development of sting theory. Many 
of our theories seem to suggest there exists some minimum distance 
possible. This "smallest" object wouldn't be a point then but rather a 
"string," "a loop," "a surface," "a membrane," or something like that. 
Matter may very well not be "point" like.

Next there is the problem that gravity is always attractive so what stops 
individual particles from collapsing under their own gravity? Well perhaps 
nothing does. Perhaps matter is made up of tiny black holes that are the 
smallest bits that could possibly exist. Maybe particles are the stable 
ground states allowed for black holes. Because quantum field theory 
suggests that objects must not have zero size and they must have ground 
energy the quantum effects of really really tiny black holes could possibly 
explain the matter/particles we see. These super tiny black holes would be 
in eigenstates (stable states) so they wouldn't give off Hawking radiation. 
If they exist in any unstable state they would quickly collapse. This 
behavior is seen in elementary particles.

Particles might be tiny black holes governed by quantum mechanical behavior.

The first part I wrote on wavepackets and the Higgs field is fairly well 
understood (the particle was found and there have been experiments showing 
a similar effect happening).

The second part is unknown. No one really knows how much mass can fit in 
one spot. No one knows what happens at the singularity of a blackhole (or 
even if a true singularity exists; there is no evidence that they do except 
in the math of a man made theory). No one has had any experiment probing 
even remotely close to the Plank length (and definitely not to zero 
length). Some kind of quantum gravity is necessary to explain matter 
however.

Particles may very well be tiny chunks of maximally curved space (most 
curvature allowed) governed by the strange effects of quantum mechanics.

comments.text:
+Corey Carnes
Neither ;)

The most accurate models to date are quantum mechanical models of the atom. 
In such models, you have electrons bound to a nucleus. Electrons are 
Fermions and interact with the nucleus through quantum electro-dynamics. 
The nucleus is made up of protons and neutrons, which themselves are mainly 
made up of quarks (Fermions) and gluons (Bosons). They are bound together 
through the strong force, but also interact through the weak, the 
electromagnetic and graviational forces.

What you end up is a huge amount of different particles and interactions. 
The mass, for instant, of an atom mainly comes from the interactions inside 
the nucleus.

So despite the point that you have a lot of energy in a small area, it is 
by far not saturated (you can always add many orders of magnitude more 
energy in such a small space). It is also very far from frozen, since it 
mainly is really the interactions that have all that energy.

In detail this is much more complicated but also much more fascinating. 
From understanding the atom, we got almost all the technology you have 
around you at the moment ... and much more is to follow ;)

comments.text:
+X4Alpha4X Look, it's clear you don't exactly know what you're talking 
about, so please don't take it the wrong way when I say you need to stop 
and read what I'm typing.

Steel, by definition, are alloys consisting of mostly iron. If you have an 
alloy consisting of mostly other stuff, then it's not steel. Many types of 
steel, even though being mostly iron, are non-magnetic. The composition 
alone does not determine its magnetic property.

Just because it is alloyed with "other non-magnetic metals" doesn't mean it 
won't be magnetic. Stainless steel, with chromium in it (an 
antiferromagnetic element), can be made to be both ferromagnetic and 
non-ferromagnetic. It depends on the crystal structure of iron.

So it's not just a matter of "mixing" one thing with another, where 
"magnetic" + "non-magnetic" = "non-magnetic". It is HOW they are mixed, and 
the process by which it is manufactured.

captions.text:
If you take a piece of wood and put it next
to another piece of wood... nothing happens.

And if you take a piece of granite and put
it next to another rock... still nothing.

But if you take this piece of iron and put
it next to this other piece of iron... magic!
I mean, magnet.

Magnetic objects are able to magically attract
at long distance because they generate magnetic

fields that extend invisibly out beyond the
object. But the mystery is this: where do
magnetic fields come from?

Derek: well that's easy, Henry! We've known
for a long time that electricity and magnetism

are really just two sides of the same coin,
kind of like mass and energy or time and space,

and they can be transformed into each other.
In fact, magnetic fields are basically just

what electric fields turn into when an electrically
charged object starts moving!

Henry: That makes sense for explaining why
a current of electrons flowing through a wire

causes this compass needle to move, or how
currents in the earth's outer core generate

the geomagnetic field... but a bar magnet
or the compass needle itself are just pieces

of metal without any electrical current running
through them.

Derek: Or are they? At a microscopic level,
there are loads of electrons whizzing around

in the atoms and molecules that make up any
solid.

Henry: Right! This brings up an excellent
point - The magnetic behavior of any everyday

object is influenced by a fascinating combination
of effects ranging from the level of particles

to atoms, collections of atoms, and collections
of collections of atoms. First, individual
particles.

Unlike the everyday workings of gravity and
electricity, permanent magnets can only be

fully understood as a quantum mechanical effect.
In much the same way that particles like electrons

and quarks have fundamental properties called
mass and electrical charge, most particles

ALSO have another intrinsic property, called
"tiny magnet". Just kidding, it's called an

"intrinsic magnetic moment," but really, that's
just technical mumbo-jumbo saying that particles

with electric charge ALSO happen to be tiny
magnets.

Derek: If you want to know WHY they're tiny
magnets, well, you might as well ask WHY do

particles have charge in the first place,
or why do objects with energy and momentum

attract gravitationally? No one knows... We
just know these things are true/that is how
the universe works.

Henry: Exactly, and since the 1920s, we've
known that each individual electron or proton

is basically a tiny magnet. Which brings us
to the level of atoms.

An atom is a bunch of positively charged protons
with a bunch of negatively charged electrons

whizzing around them. The proton tiny magnets
are about 1000 times weaker than the electron

ones, so the nucleus of the atom has almost
no effect on the magnetism of the atom as
a whole.

Derek: And you might think that since many
(though not all) of the electrons are also

moving, like the current in a wire, they would
generate magnetic fields from that motion.

Indeed they do, and these are called "orbital"
magnetic fields.

Henry: Except, these don't usually contribute
to the magnetic field of an atom. Here's why:

Electrons in atoms are accurately and complicatedly
described by quantum mechanics, but the gist

of the story is that electrons congregate
in shells around the nucleus. The electrons

in any filled shell zoom equally in all directions
and so the currents they generate cancel out

and generate no magnetic field. These electrons
also come in pairs whose tiny magnets point
in opposite directions and also cancel.

However, in a half-filled shell, all of the
electrons are unpaired and their tiny magnets

point in the same direction and add up, meaning
that it's the intrinsic magnetism of the electrons

in the outer shell that gives an atom the
majority of its magnetic field.

So atoms near the side of any of the major
blocks of the periodic table, which have full

(or nearly full) outer electron shells, aren't
very magnetic. And atoms in the MIDDLE of

the blocks have half-full outer electron shells
and are magnetic. For example, Nickel, Cobalt,
Iron, Manganese, Chromium, etc.
Derek: Wait, but chromium isn't magnetic!

Henry: Ah, but just because an atom is magnetic
doesn't mean that a material made up of lots

of that atom will be magnetic. Which brings
us to the level of crystals.

When a bunch of magnetic atoms get together
to make a solid, they generally have two options.

One is for all of the atoms to align their
magnetic fields with each other, or they can

align the magnetic fields in an alternating
fashion so that they all cancel out. The atoms
will do whichever one requires less energy.

Derek: That's why chromium, for example, is
a very magnetic atom but a very un-magnetic

solid - because it's one of the most anti-ferromagnetic
materials we know. Iron, on the other hand,

is the name-sake of ferromagnetism, so it
is, unsurprisingly, ferromagnetic. Or, in
usual parlance: magnetic.
Henry: Sometimes.

The last and final level of magnetism is that
of domains. Essentially, even in a magnetic

material where the magnetic fields of atoms
line up together, it's possible that one chunk

of the material will have all its atoms lined
up pointing one way, and another chunk will

have all its atoms pointing another way, and
so on.

Derek: If all of these "Domains" are of approximately
similar size, none may be strong enough to

force the others to align with it, and so
a piece of iron, for example, might have no

magnetic field because of all of the warring
magnetic kingdoms within it.

Henry: However, if you apply a strong enough
magnetic field/force/pressure from outside

the material, you can help favor one domain/help
one domain expand its control over its neighbors,

and so on until all of the domains have been
unified into one kingdom, all pointing in
the same direction.

Derek : And now, finally, you can rule with
an iron fist... I mean, magnet.

Henry: Exactly! What's remarkable is that
magnetism is a fundamentally quantum property

amplified to the size of everyday objects:
every permanent magnet is a reminder that

quantum mechanics underlies our universe - in
order for any object to be magnetic, it has

to have a unified kingdom of magnetic domains,
each made up of bajillions of magnetic atoms

which also need to be aligned with each other,
each of which can only be magnetic in the

first place if it has an approximately half-filled
outer shell of electrons so their intrinsic

magnetic fields can align and not cancel each
other out. Not surprisingly, these criteria

are pretty difficult to fulfill, which is
why there are only a limited number of suitable

materials you can use when you're building
a magnet.

Derek: OR you could just run a current through
any electrical conductor and generate a magnetic

field that way.
Henry: But hey... Why does that work in the

first place? Click here to go to over to Veritasium
and we'll find out what special relativity
and the speed of light have to do with electromagnets.
